segments.text: Our main problem was that both our families are very orthodox, like my dad's family as well as my mom's.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we didn't know if they would have liked me going into the industry.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That's when we decided to speak to my great-grandma.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And she was quite happy.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She looked at me and said, no, she dances so well.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She can make it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She has the talent.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was a longish road before your first hit.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I kept getting work.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I kept getting roles.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But I wasn't decided what I wanted to do.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You feel OTC now sort of creates more opportunities to write these characters of depth for women?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Absolutely.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There's a lot of comfort on the sets today.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Which was not when we were working.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We didn't have vanity fans.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We didn't have all that.

segments.text: MF Hussain.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Did you spend a lot of time with him?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What was he like?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: He kept calling you his muse.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: No, he was such a lovely person.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Do you invest your money?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: These two little boys who were just outside, you know, they used to go around with a rag and clean your car kind of.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I gave him an autograph and my name starts with an M obviously.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Madhuri Dixit and he took the thing and he looked at the M and he said, see I told you, Mohini, Mohini.

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, every failure is a failure.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So an icon for three generations of Indians, for those of us who grew up in the 80s and the 90s, we wanted to be you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I know they made a film about it later, but I remember being in school and in high school and wanting your hair and your clothes and everything about you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it's quite amazing for me to be able to have this conversation with you today.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I've admired you for so long.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Thank you for all of the work that you've done in your career and sort of raising us as young women when we were younger.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And thank you for speaking with me today.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I know that you started very young.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You were 17 when you started off.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And you were on stage much before that as well as a dancer.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yes.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I started learning Kathak at the age of three.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And so I had a lot of dance performances.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And, you know, me and my sister used to perform together as well.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And even through school, I used to be on stage all the time, whether it's singing or elocution or, you know, doing plays or dancing or
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Anything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I used to be on stage, always.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And you grew up in Mumbai, but you were not from a film family.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: No, I was.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So what was that?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, did you think of it first saying, I want to be in films or did the family think, oh, she'd be good in films?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How did that happen?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: No, actually what happened was that someone we knew worked in the Rajshri office and they were looking for a youngster, like a young girl to play a child bride in a movie called Abodh.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he came to us and he said, since Madhuri is so well known to be on stage in her school and she dances so well, she has a national talent scholarship and I've seen her dance and she's so good and would you like to try?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because they're looking for a young girl.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we had never thought about being in films or anything of that sort.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And my family was, no, no, no, we don't think so.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She's going to do her studies and that's what my mom told him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he came back, he said, no, just meet them at least once.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Just come to the office and meet the people.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They are amazing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And Tarachanji was alive at that time.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he said, just meet them.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It's a lovely family and you feel like you're meeting your own family.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Just come and meet them.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So that kind of convinced us and me and my mom and my dad, we went to the office to meet them.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Tarachanji was there and Raj Babuji was there.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we met them and they spoke to us.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They made me read a little book.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was about the author, the back of the book in Hindi.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So they said, can you read this for us?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I did.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And they were like, oh good, you don't have a Marathi accent.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Why do you speak Hindi?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So they just wanted to check that out.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But we met them and we thought they were such nice people, down to earth, you know, very family oriented.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And so nice to meet, so nice to talk, so down to earth.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we went back like scratching our heads.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we were like, oh my God, they're such nice people.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because till then, we all had this impression of, you know, the Bollywood movie.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, like that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we were like quite taken aback.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we went back and we started thinking about this.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And my mom was like, what do you want to do?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I was like, I would like to try.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I would like to, I mean, I love to act.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I love to dance and I love to do all that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we said, let's audition.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we did the audition and everything and we came back and they liked the audition.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And they said, we really like her or you know, we might cast her, but we don't know yet.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We haven't decided and stuff.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we came back.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But our main problem was that both our families are very orthodox, like my dad's family as well as my mom's.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we didn't know if they would have liked me going into the industry and, you know, in the film industry.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we had to speak to them.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's when we decided to speak to my great grandma.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She was still alive at that point.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we talked to her and we said, you know, she's getting an offer.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Nothing is done yet, but she is getting an offer.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And what should we do?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What do you think?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: If you say that, no, she should not go, we will respect your wishes and she will not.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And she was quite, she looked at me and said, no, she dances so well.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And you know, she is really hardworking and I think she can make it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She has the talent.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And if she works hard, she will make it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we have no objections to her going into the film industry.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we were like, oh my God, what's happening?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And then we waited for, you know, the Rajshri's to call back and nothing happened.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And there was no news from them for like two, three months.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I was like in college and I said, mom, they are not going to call now.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I was like, I'm going to cut my hair.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So she said, no, no, no, don't cut your hair.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They were not very long, but they were long enough that, you know, for the film, it would have been great.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And finally she said, okay, go cut your hair.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I used to like,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That hair.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I used to really cut them short.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I went and chopped my hair off.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They called.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They called.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: The next week they called.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I went to the office and Raj Babuji nearly had a panic attack.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He said, what have you done to your hair?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I said, I didn't know that I would be selected.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You are selected and everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And the director is coming down and we will do some scenes from the movie.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So they put a wig on me, big old wig on me, big hair, long hair.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we did the little final auditions, you know, scenes from the movie and the director loved my work and they all were like, okay, she's on board.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's how my first film happened.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They wanted to start in March and my mom was like, no, no, no, you can't start in March, April.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She has exams.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was my 12th exams happened then.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And they said, okay, we wait for her, let her finish exams and then we start.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So that's how
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So you went 16?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: 16, 17 when you did.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it was, if I'm not mistaken, it was a longish road before your first hit, before this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yes.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Four years, five years, from 17 to 21 or more?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: From 84 to 88.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, four years.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And the thing was that I kept getting work, I kept getting roles, but I wasn't decided what I wanted to do because
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: you know, education was so important for my family.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I thought maybe because I was a science student after a board, I went back to college and I started doing microbiology and we didn't know where we wanted to be.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I wanted to do this and that both.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I said, I can do my studies.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And because I was getting roles with LV Prasad productions, very good productions, but since
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They were offering me roles which took only a small amount of your time, like 10 days, 15 days.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I did Swati and Meenakshi Sheshadri was the main lead.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I did Awa Rabab.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Again Meenakshi Sheshadri was the main lead and I was playing the second lead.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But it suited me because just 10-15 days of work and I could go back to my studies.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's how I ended up doing a song in Karma, Subhaji's film.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He said that, you know, I really like your work.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I love the way you dance and everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So you have to stop doing these small roles that you've been doing and just decide what you want to do, whether you want to do films or go back to your studies.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Commit if this is what you really want to do.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's when I thought, yes, you know, I love what I do and
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I want to be in films.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's when I decided.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And then, you know, I was signed for Ram Lakan.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I did so many films before that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I did which were the films.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So they were like, I think a slew of films.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'd done six, seven, eight films before Tezab happened.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And of course, when Tezab happened, then it, you know, everything, everything changed.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Everything changed.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But Mr. Shubhashkar played a massive role in
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: pulling you out of, you know, obscurity and putting you on stage.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Kind of introducing, because he was going to introduce me into his films, like sign me for his films.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Then he had to kind of mount me as someone to look forward to and, you know, break that imagery of me doing smaller roles in films and kind of giving it a new, kind of a new chapter in my life.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, back then he ran a newspaper campaign, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Sort of launching your face?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: For screen.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yes.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we had these little things in screen where my eyes appeared first, then, you know, some more part of my face and then the full face appeared.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he said that, you know, this girl is going to be signed by me and I'm introducing her in Ram Lakan.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yes.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: How did, you know, at that age, when you were effectively a teenager and you were signing these films, you were working with big actors,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How did you manage to sort of keep your head about you?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think I credit that to my mom.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She always used to be with me and she's the one who used to bring me back to earth and give me that strength that you need.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She was my backbone basically throughout.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So if people criticize me, they say, oh, she's too thin, she's too skinny, just do this, just go, you know, make her put on some weight, and you know, because I was very young at the time, and so I used to be like, mom, they're saying this, and she used to say, don't worry.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Don't worry about anything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She says, once your film is successful, they will praise you exactly for the things that they're criticizing you today.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So don't even think about it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You are good the way you are.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Just keep working, do a good job every time you go on the set,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: work sincerely, do your best.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And once you get the recognition, people will forget about all these little things they've been talking about.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Something you now, and you're raising young men yourself now, you have two boys, is that something that you're pushing forward?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Because dealing with failure and disappointment is a particular challenge for this generation of young people.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What are you telling them as a mom?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Well, I always tell them that failures are not
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: a failing point.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Look at failures as a learning process, you know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Whenever you fail, it is not the end of the world.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You have to learn from your failure and move ahead.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So those are the stumbling blocks or something that teaches you, you know, and you move forward.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Don't look at it as something that did not work.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Look at it something that taught you what you have to do to make it work.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So that's what I keep telling them all the time.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I said, don't be afraid of failures.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, you need failures in life to actually grow and rise, you know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: The Thezab success of Iqdutin, which, you know, it was, it was marquee because people were going into the theater just to see the song, then apparently leaving after.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It changed your life.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What was that like?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It was wonderful because finally,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: People recognized me.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I have a recognition for my talent, for the amount of work I put in, all the scenes in the films.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was a very different film for a regular commercial cinema actress, like the whole relationship between me and my father and all those kind of things.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There were a lot of scenes in the film which brought out a different personality of me, a different part of me.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I really thoroughly enjoyed working on that film and N. Chandra because he was like a guide throughout, you know, and guiding me with every scene, every little thing we did.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I think it kind of suddenly put me in the forefront.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I enjoyed every bit of it, I have to say.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: The recognition, like I landed on the airport.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I was not here when the film released.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I was in the US.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So when I came back,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There's these two little, I always tell this incident because it's very close to my heart and these two little boys who were just outside, you know, they used to go around with a rag and clean your car kind of, and they looked at me and one of them said, I think one, two, three, one, two, three.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I noticed that and I said, Oh my God, somebody was sitting there.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So then he came to me and says, Madam, autograph, autograph.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I gave him an autograph and my name starts with an M obviously.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I wrote Madhuri Dixit and he took the thing and he looked at the M and he said,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: See, I told you, Mohini, Mohini!
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So suddenly I was being known as a character I played in a movie and everybody was like Mohini and that recognition that everything just like validates, you know, everything that you were.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, a lot of times people who are watching the films, especially back then, didn't realize that the songs that you're known for involved, you know, 10 hours, 15 hours, maybe even more.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: of filming where you do these things over and over again, over and over again, in order to get it right.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Is there a work ethic there that you still hold?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Absolutely, absolutely.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: My work ethic is something that's, when I'm on the sets, I'm on the set, I'm all there, you know, I'm present, I'm in the moment.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Even when we did the song, Ik Dho Teen,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: we had to break the set the next day.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we worked all day, all night, and we packed up the next day at 10.30 in the morning.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So those kind of work ethics, that once you've got to do it, you've got to prove yourself.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You just have to, yeah.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because as the lead or the heroine, as you were called back then, there are a hundred people on the set, but they're all dependent on you getting it right for them to finish their day.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They're all waiting for...
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Oh, she's gonna get it right.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If she gets it wrong, we're all staying back until she gets it right.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, that's a lot of pressure.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's a lot of pressure, but you know, we have lovely directors, like even the choreographers like Sarol Ji or they all were so supportive and they always encouraged us.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They always like, were behind us.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Ho jayega, don't worry.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Ek aur kar lete, chalo ek aur, you know, like that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I think it all worked out fine.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You've got a new show coming out and you're obviously spending considerable amounts of time on sets as well.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But when you compare the sets and the way work was done back in the 80s and 90s too.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: what's happening now, which is very professional, very regimented.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, they're not holding up dupattas for you to change your clothes on location.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What strikes you as the things that have changed the most?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What was it like back then, to be honest?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think there's a lot of comfort on the sets today, which was not when we were working.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We didn't have vanity vans, we didn't have all that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So even if we are shooting in an outdoor, we are on some part somewhere, you know, on a mountain,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We just used to change in the car or like you said, somebody who held up the shawls or whatever and we changed behind it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But today I think there's a lot of comfort, you know, there's a lot of things they make tents, they make things for you to sit.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They will make sure that you're as comfortable as possible so that the shoot goes on, you know, as planned and everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's why it was like, whatever, you have to do that and then you still have to shoot and give it your all, you know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So, in that sense, it's much more organized.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, everything is... You have the whole bound script with you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They've worked out everything from what you're going to wear to how you're going to look and how the scene is going to be shot.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Everything is done beforehand.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So, once you go on the set, it's all set.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You don't have to think of everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But then...
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Films used to be shot, like, sporadically.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Not like today.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You have three months and you finish...
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: the whole film in those three months, or the series in those three months.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And you're done.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And then you move on to the next.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Or you want to take a break, you can do that and move on to the next.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But at that time, it was like very sporadic.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we used to shoot for 10 days.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And then we never knew when we'll shoot for the same film again.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Unless, of course, it was Yesh Chopra or a Subhash Ghai or a Rajshri Productions, who are much more organized.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: By and large we used to shoot like that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And sometimes films would run out of money and they would take a break and you didn't know when they would come back.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yes, yes.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So sometimes continuity used to go for a toss.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because after one year we lost the saree.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: The saree has gone somewhere.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: The hair, they don't know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There's a picture of the continuity.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we just can't do it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I remember doing this maybe something like this.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So, you know, just do the hair which you think is very similar.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But yeah, those used to be a lot of problems.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But I think there was a lot of warmth.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There's a lot of camaraderie.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was a lot of because we used to sit on the set like this and talk to each other and, you know, eat from each other's ears and, you know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What's from your house?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So those kind of things.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But today I think it's very organized.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But for an actor, it's a dream today.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Media is also very different now, right?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, you were the top heroine during the days of Cine Blitz and Stardust and all of that part truth, part gossip type of stuff that was being written.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And now, obviously, I know that you're active on Instagram and social media, and there's a completely different world with the paps and things like that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Which of these two worlds do you prefer?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I don't know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think there's this plus and minus to everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There's so much media.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, there's so much happening.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There's Insta, there's Twitter, there's this, there's that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And everything good comes with everything bad.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So you just have to accept the fact that once you put yourself out there anywhere on Insta or Twitter, there's going to be good, there's going to be bad, there's going to be ugly, there's going to be everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And it's all very there for you to see.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Maybe in that era, the magazines used to write something, but by and large, you never knew who's thinking what.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, now you know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Exactly how people think and sometimes it's like, oh my God, is that really?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: People can think that way, they can write something like this, but then it's part of human nature.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It takes all kinds to make this movie.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, the other person I know who played a role in your career was Gautam Rajdakshya, the photographer.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: His work sort of punctuated various points of your career.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Absolutely.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: When did you meet him?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What was that relationship like?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Oh my God, the first time I met him was, I think it was in 1987 when I had gone to his house because
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: all his photo sessions used to be done in his own house, because he has his backgrounds, he had everything there.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I remember... Back then, backgrounds were painted.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Oh yes, painted on rolls and they used to set it up like that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So his house was big enough that he had everything organized out there.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So the first time I went, I remember it was like, oh my God, I'm going to Kautam Rajateksha's house and he's going to be photographing me.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I was
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Kind of I knew that he's a big name, but not completely like the impact of it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I remember I walked in and he's like, he took one look at me and he says, huh, you know, he's talking like that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You say, why have you like gone over your lip?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You have a lovely lip line.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Can you just remove that and do it again?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Or just do your lips normally like that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I was like quite taken aback, you know, photographer telling me that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I'm like, okay.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I very demurely I did that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: beautiful photo session we did together.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he was amazing as a person.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He was so giving and he was like, he was like a father figure, you know, right there.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he used to guide me on how, how I should be standing, how, you know, let's do this, let's try that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we had a lot of fun in his house.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And Mickey Contractor used to
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: do my makeup and him and it's nostalgia completely.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I read a story once where you had some, you had an acne breakout and he found a way to shoot you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And, um, that, that was, that was amazing because today, you know, you just an instant, you can take it out and Photoshop it and it's gone.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But at that time, you know, what you, what you shot was what you had.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And, uh, he kind of.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: blended the light and what he did and it was amazing what he did with the pictures.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So he was someone who was really so talented.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He was a magician.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he used to bring out your personality.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was like you could see the person instead of just a picture or a dolled up picture.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Tell me about Mrs. Deshpande because I saw a little bit of the teaser, the trailer.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's a very layered character.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It is.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So it's not just the maternal bond, which is by itself complicated.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's also crime.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's also sinister.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's a lot of things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Why did you choose it?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What about this project drew you to it?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think, first of all, I love the fact that she's such a multi-layered character.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She can be very ordinary.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, you just look at her.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: The ambiguity is there.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She's just a housewife.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She's so calm.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She's composed.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She's quiet.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She doesn't have to raise her voice, but she can make someone feel really uncomfortable, you know, just with the silences or with her calmness, you know, and she can just say something and just shake people up.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And so I thought that that power that she has, I thought that was amazing, you know, and of course her whole history, her, her, um,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: backstory adds to whoever she is.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Plus, like you said, a very complicated kind of relationship, which also plays on everybody's mind.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And also the fact that even though she's working so closely with authorities, with the police, but it's not based on trust.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It's just based on the fact that something heinous is happening and we need to stop that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's why they need her help.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Can you really trust her?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She can be someone who can be spinning her own thing on the side saying that I'm out but I have something else on my mind as well.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So all these things, you know, that just adds to the mystery of her character.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I thought it would be wonderful to play her.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And of course, Nagesh Kukanoor is directing it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I have seen his past work and I've been an admirer.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I loved Door, COD, City of Dreams, his latest Hunt, or Hyderabad Blues, or Iqbal, all these films I had seen.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I was very, very, I loved his work.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And then when he approached me as a director for this,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I was like, yeah, I would love to do it, because he's also a director who can extract that performance from you and keep the narrative and everything very precise, very concise, and not stray here and there.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And applause, of course, was behind this whole project, who have done such good work before.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I said, yes, I would love to do this role.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Also, it makes it
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I can do something different, you know, from what I've done so far.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So it's not glamorous, she's not like, oh, beautiful and all that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She's like, she's someone who's very real, very, very raw, very off the earth, you know, and that's what I liked about her.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You feel OTC now sort of creates more opportunities to write these, you know, characters of depth for women?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Absolutely.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Absolutely.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's how I've, you know, done Fame Game or Majama because
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It just gives me a chance to do something very different from what theatrical release will have.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, theater is when you put a movie in a theater, you are bound by certain things that you think of.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: This is the audience.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You have to please everyone in the audience.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And so a lot of compromises are done to make a script palatable to everyone.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But here, since there are no constraints of that kind,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: you can create stuff that is like just out of the box and just left of the field or the right of the field, absolutely.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's why Mrs. Deshpande was so important for me to do, or a majama or a fame game.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It gave me something so different to do, so dramatic.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And also it gives you time to create your character and create that mystery and everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I think that's how
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It does and also because of OTT, you also discover so much fresh talent as well.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: How do you mean?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: In a sense, there's so much talent which doesn't have to look a particular way or be a particular way or, you know, the talented people who have just come and just captured your imagination, young people who have come, you know, with dreams in their eyes and they're here and they're doing such a good job, like they're acting so well.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And so that kind of discovery has the OTT has made it possible to do that and tell like stories which are so diverse and and
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: the world cinemas in front of you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You get to see different cultures and you get to learn about so many different things, but I find that what finally boils down to is emotions and that's the same everywhere.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We have the same issues, we have the same problem, but you see the same thing, but in set in a different culture.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That makes it very interesting.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I thought it was interesting because in the
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: In the blockbuster films that you did in the 90s, for example, there wasn't as much space for acting in the silences, which I know you've done here in Mrs. Deshpande, where a lot of the work is just with your face, but without saying anything.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But back then, it was like very crowd pleasing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It was either you're either crying or you're, you know, there's no... Yeah, I would like tend to disagree to that because
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I did films which had a lot of silences, too, like a prahar.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: See, for every Dil Toh Bhaagal I did, there was a Mrityudhan, you know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's the way I was brought up, actually, because my dad used to read the newspaper, see the reviews, and then take us to watch films.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we had seen a lot of Shabanas, those kind of films, which were art house films at that time.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we grew up on that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And when I started working in films, then when I was doing commercial films as well,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: there was always something very powerful and I was very fortunate that I got to play those kind of roles whether it's beta or a Raja where you know she's completely like dominating everything that's happening or a Lajja or a Mrityudand or you know so I got to do these different kind of roles which not only were commercial but also like Mrityudand had a lot of silences and there were a lot of things in that and
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: or I had done a film called Sangeet, where I learned a lot from the director K. Vishwanath Ji or Prem Pratigya, which Bapu Garu had directed.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I think every commercial film, there was something that I was doing, which was commercial, but yet it had those little nuances that, you know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What was the, what's the interesting challenge now with, you know, with the work that you're doing with television or with OTT?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What are the challenges?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think sky's the limit for OTT, I feel, because the challenging thing is to select roles that you want to do, like Mrs. Deshpande.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Why did you think I did it?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because number one is on OTT.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Secondly, it brought to me something that I haven't done before.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And it's something that I want to really sink my teeth into and say, this is something I want to play.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When you were at the top of your career as a heroine back then, the three Khans, Shah Rukh, Salman and Amar, all of whom you worked with, were still finding their audiences.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They were building their careers at that time.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Are you still in touch with all of them?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Are you part of their memories of how they built their career when you see how their careers have been built up till now?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yeah, I mean, in the sense, I worked with them.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think I worked with Shah Rukh when he just had done Circus and a few of those things and I did Anjam with him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So, Rahul said, you know, that there was this new boy, he's so good and this and that and that I'd met Shah Rukh to do Anjam and I looked at him and I was like, he was so
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So unassuming, so cute, and you know, like the hair like on his...
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But what caught me were his eyes.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, there's so much depth in his eyes and there's something really attractive about that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Or even when I worked with Amir, he had just had...
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So he was also fairly new, though he had a release and it was a big hit and everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And when I worked with Salman, again, he was a rising star in that time.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When we worked together in Ham Aap Ke Hain Kaun or Sajan and all those films.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They were like on the rise and on the go at that point.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When you look back at your career, obviously successes and failures as everybody has had.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What has been your secret in dealing with failure?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Do you remember moments
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: where you thought that, Oh my God, I don't want to do this anymore.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And you found a way to move past it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do you, how do you process failure?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do you deal with it?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, every failure should get me angry in the sense it made me feel that I need to get out of this and I need to prove myself.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So every failure I looked at as like I tell my kids as a learning curve, you know, and I always used to feel that when I've done a film, I've been on the set, I've done my best.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, I've worked sincerely.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I have given it all.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Now I step back, the film releases, whether it does well or it doesn't do well, I have done my best.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I can rest assured that from my side, there's been no cheating or nothing that, you know, I've given it my all.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But if the film doesn't do well, then it's part of like how films are.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Like some films work, some films don't work.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But of course, sometimes it does hurt you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You do feel bad.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But then it used to give me that rigor, that anger again, that saying that, nah, I'm going to prove myself.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'm going to do the next film, which is going to be even better.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So that's how I looked at failure.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Tell me what it was like when you decided to come back to your career from the US.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, I know everybody's asked you about your decision to leave, but your decision to come back because your husband had a thriving practice.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: He came back with you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You brought the kids back with you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Did you know what you were planning on doing with your career?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Were you nervous?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Say, oh my God, is it going to work out?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: See, every decision you make, of course, there's a little bit of nervousness in the sense that, oh, we're going to a new thing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But for me, I was just coming back home.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So there was nothing to get nervous about.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What motivated that?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, there were a lot of things that happened.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: My parents were living with me and, you know, they wanted to come back because they were getting old.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They wanted to be where, you know, they have grown up and, you know, it's comfortable here for them.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: My kids were growing up and, you know, I was getting a lot of offers from here.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I was coming here, working, going back.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I was finding that very hard to continue doing because it
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It means a lot of time away from my kids and away from home.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And Ram was also like, he wanted to do something different.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He was a cardiothoracic surgeon and he had worked 20 years.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And, you know, he said, I'm operating on people, you know, after the fact, you know, after everything is done and after they got sick, then they came to me and I'm operating on them and getting them better.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But what if I can get them
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: before it happens.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So there was something growing in his mind what he wanted to do, something that's different from what he was doing and I want to come back.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And everybody thought that my parents were the main deciding factor and I said, okay, let's go back.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Let's do this, let's go back.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we had all the plans and everything before we made the move.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When you're raising your children now, especially in the age of social media and it's a
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's perhaps a harsher time to be a teenager or to be a young person now than it has ever been before.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Does that worry you?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that's not an India or a US thing that's currently just the way the world is.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do you navigate that as a parent?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Well, you know, sometimes you feel scared for your kids because not everybody is that strong.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Not everybody can have, you know, that, um,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Resilience or that intelligence to know, you know, this is like, okay, you know, don't deal with this, this is what you got to deal with.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And then that navigation becomes a little difficult for them.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But I think when you have given them the values, you know, like they grew up with my parents, so they grew up with their grandparents, they learned so much from them.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We are trying to impart, you know, the best thing that we can do for them
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: giving them the values, respect everyone, don't take things for granted, work hard for everything you do.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we are giving them everything we can.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we're trying to raise kids who are strong, kids who can stand on their own feet, and kids who can
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: you know, stand up for themselves, you know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we are trying to do that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we just hope that once they go into the world, they will use those tools that we have already placed in front of them, given them, and they will navigate life, you know, according to what we've taught them.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But of course, there will be ups and downs in everybody's lives and how you deal with that becomes, you know, the crux of everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But you're a stunning woman and
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: right now in this whole era of social media and the way that young girls are growing up, constantly comparing themselves to people that they see on screen.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Do you feel that there's more pressure on young people to look a certain way, even at a very young age?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Do you feel that there's more pressure on women, more pressure to do with aging?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What is your message on
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Well, I would say the same thing that my mom told me.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You have to be comfortable in your own skin.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: This is who you are.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And you don't... How do I put it?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What you do with your life is more important than what you look like or that one instant that you took that picture.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What you do with your life, how you lead your life,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: you know, stay healthy, that's the most important thing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do good things, work hard.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You just concentrate on those aspects of your life that makes you who you are.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Is there one sort of Riyaz or habit that you still follow that you've been doing through your career?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yeah, dance.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, it's something that I have to do and I practice my Kathak still.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Every day?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Not every day, it's not possible every day.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But whenever I can, like twice a week, once a week, or I love to dance, so I might just take up, you know, I do shows and I do all that because I want to keep dancing, you know, I want to keep in that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because it just makes me feel good.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It's very spiritual for me.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It also adds a lot to who you are.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Actually, for,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: people in their 20s now who are starting their career and you started at 17, what is that one piece of advice you'll give them?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Because you've displayed a career of longevity over decades where you've kept doing new things, you kept coming back, you know, you had the stamina to sort of keep going.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What advice would you give someone starting a career in any job?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, love what you do and do what you love because you will never tire of it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You will never feel like
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When you're forced to do something, then it becomes an issue.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But if you do something you love, you're passionate about, I think you won't work a day in your life.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You'll just be excited to go every day and do something amazing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, the person I've always wanted to ask you about is M.F.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Hussain.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What was he like?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Did you spend a lot of time with him?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What was he like?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: He kept calling you his muse.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: No, he was such a lovely person.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I remember he had come to visit Denver to my house and he said, I've always seen you as, you know, Madhuri Dixit, the actress and you know everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Now I want to see Madhuri Dixit, the mother, because I had both my sons at that time.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I said, yes, you're most welcome.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Please come.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he came to visit us and
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He said, oh, now I got to paint.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I said, no, no, Musenji, don't do that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Just sit, just relax.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, I'll make you some tea.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You can sip on your tea and just relax and not do anything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He says, why are you punishing me?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I said, why?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He says, I'm most relaxed when I paint.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's exactly how I feel about my art.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, I'm most comfortable when I'm
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: in front of the camera when I'm playing these different characters.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think I'm most comfortable at that time.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I just kind of, I said, Hussainji, you know, you just made me realize, you know, about myself too, when you said that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And a lovely person and he used to love what he did.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, every house he went to, he just bought a lot of goodwill and laughter.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And, you know, he was,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He had a lovely sense of humor and he used to be like...
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When he came to visit me, he had nothing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He just had a roll-away bag with him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I thought maybe he has his clothes in the roll-away bag.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And so I came home and I said... Then he said, now bring the canvas.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I have to paint.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I'm like, but we'll have to get paints too.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He says, no, no.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Here are the paints.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So the roll-away bag was full of paints.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I said, then where are your clothes?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What are you going to wear?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He said, what is this?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do I have to wear this shirt?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Or inside...
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He had worn his night pajamas inside and he was wearing the shirt and pant on the top because it was cold in Denver.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He said, that's it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I said, okay, let's go shopping now.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I also want to know for someone who started earning when you were 17, do you manage your own money?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Did you invest your money, you know, in your twenties?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How did you handle the money that came with the success?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yeah, the problem I'll tell you, when I started working at first, you know,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was just like small sums of money and we just did the, you know, a little bit of...
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But once I started working, I was so busy.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I didn't have time to do anything, let alone look after my money.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So my dad used to do stuff.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But I learned how to manage money and everything after I got married.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That was when I really started learning how to from my husband.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: because he's very good at it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he always teaches me, you know, about how to invest and how to invest, where to invest, how to find out about companies and you know, all that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I would say that I knew very little about money management before, but a lot now.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When you were talking about MFSN visiting you in Denver, and he said, if you keep me away from my art, that's punishing me, there's some
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: point in your heart you felt that you're away from your art as well, because you had taken quite a substantial break.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yeah, but I was living my dream.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It's like, everybody has dreams for themselves, like you want to do this, that, and the other.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: For me, having a family was a big part of it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: because we are four siblings and we came from a big family and I loved kids.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So that's something that was very important.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So for me, being married, having kids and having a house, that was a part of my dream.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So when I was doing that, I was living a dream.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And of course, work is also a very important part of your life because that's your own personal selfish thing that you want to do.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Not selfish, but
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I would say that some things that you do, you feed your soul.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I felt that I missed my craft, but I loved every minute of those five years.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That was a way too.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think it's very interesting for me because I feel that our generation of women, unlike our mothers, who some of them did work,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: but it wasn't such a large part of their identity.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: For us, our jobs are such a large part of identity.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So along with having the family and the children, everything.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: See, my mom, in those days, like we were, she had four kids and she loved to sing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So she was, she did her BA, Bachelor of Arts, in between, like having two kids, she had done that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And then after having four kids, she completed her master MA with vocal Hindustani music.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So she also had that drive, you know, towards getting away.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She used to love singing and she used to love to dance and that's how we love dancing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And she taught us to dance because she couldn't do it when she was little.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: She was, I mean, they gave her permission that you can sing, but you cannot dance.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And when it came to us, she was like, I want my daughters to dance.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And she taught us to dance.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And she did all that with looking after the four kids and doing her thing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So when you see that,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: in your own house, it kind of creates that discipline in you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, you learn from your parents.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's what I learned from her, that how she managed everything and yet did something that she loved.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You've, I mean, you've met him multiple times because you all worked in the same industry.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You also worked together briefly.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yes.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, in one of the films, like we have a little
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: kids at that time when we worked with him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And what a gentleman.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, I've met him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I used to love his song.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So for me, Dharmendra was that, you know, the handsome man and striking man.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And then when I met him, I was like tongue tied.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I told him, I said, I was a big fan of yours.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And he's so, he was so gentle.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He's such a nice person.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He was so sweet, down to earth and very grounded, you know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And so, great admiration for him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We've lost a big star.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We've lost a very big star.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And not just that, a lovely person.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Madhuri ji, thank you so much for spending time with me and answering all my questions.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I wish you very, very good luck and all the best for Mrs. Deshpande.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I'm sure it's going to be a massive hit.
